item.name: Breastplate of the Naïve
item.text:
This armor consists of a fitted metal chest piece worn with supple leather. Although it leaves the legs and arms relatively unprotected, this armor provides good protection for the wearer's vital organs while leaving the wearer relatively unencumbered.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Chain Mail of the Naïve
item.text:
Made of interlocking metal rings, chain mail includes a layer of quilted fabric worn underneath the mail to prevent chafing and to cushion the impact of blows. The suit includes gauntlets.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 13, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Chain Shirt of the Naïve
item.text:
Made of interlocking metal rings, a chain shirt is worn between layers of clothing or leather. This armor offers modest protection to the wearer's upper body and allows the sound of the rings rubbing against one another to be muffled by outer layers.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 144

item.name: Half Plate Armor of the Naïve
item.text:
Half plate consists of shaped metal plates that cover most of the wearer's body. It does not include leg protection beyond simple greaves that are attached with leather straps.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Hide Armor of the Naïve
item.text:
This crude armor consists of thick furs and pelts. It is commonly worn by barbarian tribes, evil humanoids, and other folk who lack access to the tools and materials needed to create better armor.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 144

item.name: Leather Armor of the Naïve
item.text:
The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 144

item.name: Padded Armor of the Naïve
item.text:
Padded armor consists of quilted layers of cloth and batting.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 144

item.name: Plate Armor of the Naïve
item.text:
Plate consists of shaped, interlocking metal plates to cover the entire body. A suit of plate includes gauntlets, heavy leather boots, a visored helmet, and thick layers of padding underneath the armor. Buckles and straps distribute the weight over the body.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 15, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Ring Mail of the Naïve
item.text:
This armor is leather armor with heavy rings sewn into it. The rings help reinforce the armor against blows from swords and axes. Ring mail is inferior to chain mail, and it's usually worn only by those who can't afford better armor.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Scale Mail of the Naïve
item.text:
This armor consists of a coat and leggings (and perhaps a separate skirt) of leather covered with overlapping pieces of metal, much like the scales of a fish. The suit includes gauntlets.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 144

item.name: Splint Armor of the Naïve
item.text:
This armor is made of narrow vertical strips of metal riveted to a backing of leather that is worn over cloth padding. Flexible chain mail protects the joints.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 15, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Studded Leather Armor of the Naïve
item.text:

While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.

Padded armor consists of quilted layers of cloth and batting.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 144

item.name: Plate Armor of the Witless
item.text:
Plate consists of shaped, interlocking metal plates to cover the entire body. A suit of plate includes gauntlets, heavy leather boots, a visored helmet, and thick layers of padding underneath the armor. Buckles and straps distribute the weight over the body.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 15, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Ring Mail of the Witless
item.text:
This armor is leather armor with heavy rings sewn into it. The rings help reinforce the armor against blows from swords and axes. Ring mail is inferior to chain mail, and it's usually worn only by those who can't afford better armor.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Scale Mail of the Witless
item.text:
This armor consists of a coat and leggings (and perhaps a separate skirt) of leather covered with overlapping pieces of metal, much like the scales of a fish. The suit includes gauntlets.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 144

item.name: Splint Armor of the Witless
item.text:
This armor is made of narrow vertical strips of metal riveted to a backing of leather that is worn over cloth padding. Flexible chain mail protects the joints.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
The wearer has disadvantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.
If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 15, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 145

item.name: Studded Leather Armor of the Witless
item.text:
Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 144

item.name: Breastplate Barding of the Witless
item.detail: tack and harness, very rare (requires attunement)
item.text:
This armor consists of a fitted metal chest piece worn with supple leather. Although it leaves the legs and arms relatively unprotected, this armor provides good protection for the wearer's vital organs while leaving the wearer relatively unencumbered.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
Barding is armor designed to protect an animal's head, neck, chest, and body.
Breastplate barding provides a mount with an AC of 14.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 157

item.name: Chain Barding of the Witless
item.detail: tack and harness, very rare (requires attunement)
item.text:
Made of interlocking metal rings, chain mail includes a layer of quilted fabric worn underneath the mail to prevent chafing and to cushion the impact of blows.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
Barding is armor designed to protect an animal's head, neck, chest, and body.
Chain barding provides a mount with an AC of 16, and reduces the mount's speed by 10 feet unless its Strength score is 13 or better. The mount makes Dexterity (Stealth) checks with disadvantage.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 157

item.name: Chain Shirt Barding of the Witless
item.detail: tack and harness, very rare (requires attunement)
item.text:
Made of interlocking metal rings, a chain shirt is worn between layers of clothing or leather. This armor offers modest protection to the wearer's upper body and allows the sound of the rings rubbing against one another to be muffled by outer layers.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
Barding is armor designed to protect an animal's head, neck, chest, and body.
Chain shirt barding provides a mount with an AC of 13.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 157

item.name: Half Plate Barding of the Witless
item.detail: tack and harness, very rare (requires attunement)
item.text:
Half plate consists of shaped metal plates that cover most of the wearer's body. It does not include leg protection beyond simple greaves that are attached with leather straps.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.
Barding is armor designed to protect an animal's head, neck, chest, and body.
Half plate barding provides a mount with an AC equal to 15 + the mount's Dexterity modifier (max 2). The mount makes Dexterity (Stealth) checks with disadvantage.
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 66 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 157

item.name: Hide Barding of the Witless
item.detail: tack and harness, very rare (requires attunement)
item.text:

item.detail: tack and harness, very rare (requires attunement)

item.name: Bloodseeker Battleaxe
item.text:
This weapon is adorned with small black spikes that seem to soak up any blood that splashes across them. This acts as a +1 weapon and provides you with 1d8 temporary hit points whenever you reduce a Dragon, Giant, Humanoid or Monstrosity to 0 hit points.
Versatile: This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.
Proficiency: martial, battleaxe Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 67 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 149

item.name: Bloodseeker Blowgun
item.text:
Ammo: blowgun needle
This weapon is adorned with small black spikes that seem to soak up any blood that splashes across them. This acts as a +1 weapon and provides you with 1d8 temporary hit points whenever you reduce a Dragon, Giant, Humanoid or Monstrosity to 0 hit points.
Ammunition: You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. The ammunition of a firearm is destroyed upon use. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield. If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon (see "Improvised Weapons").
Range: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.
Loading: Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.
Proficiency: martial, blowgun Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 67 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 149

This crude armor consists of thick furs and pelts. It is commonly worn by barbarian tribes, evil humanoids, and other folk who lack access to the tools and materials needed to create better armor.
This armor is forged of cold iron, a magical material that protects the wearer against fey magic. While wearing it, you have advantage on saving throws against the spells and other magical effects of fey creatures, as well as on saving throws to resist the memory loss caused by the feywild.
Barding is armor designed to protect an animal's head, neck, chest, and body.
Hide barding provides a mount with an AC equal to 12 + the mount's Dexterity modifier (max 2).
Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 67 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 157

item.name: Mithral Blowgun
item.text:
Ammo: blowgun needle
Mithral is a light, flexible metal. If a weapon normally has the Heavy property, the mithral version doesn't. If a weapon normally has the Finesse property, the mithral version also has the Light property.
Ammunition: You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. The ammunition of a firearm is destroyed upon use. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield. If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon (see "Improvised Weapons").
Range: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.
Loading: Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.
Proficiency: martial, blowgun Source: Tasha's Crucible of Everything Else - Volume 1 p. 67 (Homebrew), Player's Handbook (2014) p. 149
